Graphical abstract A high-stable Nb2O5/Nb2CTX heterostructure as electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (ENRR) catalyst is fabricated. It enables a Zn-N2 battery system with a high-power density of 1.25 mW cm−2 and a continuous net NH3 production capacity. Aqueous Zn-N2 batteries with unique configuration are of potential for simultaneous N2 electroreduction and electricity generation, in which the electrocatalysts are critical for improving the NH3 yield and the energy efficiency. Herein, a heterostructure Nb2O5/Nb2CTX with abundant exposed Nb active sites and tuned electron density has been synthesized by in situ formation and anchoring of Nb2O5 nanoparticles on the surface of Nb2CTX MXene, which shows an enhanced N2 adsorption/activation capacity. The heterostructure Nb2O5/Nb2CTX was used as the cathode of Zn-N2 battery that can deliver a peak power density of 1.25 mW cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH and can continuously produce NH3 with a yield of 3.62 μg h−1 mgcat −1. The NH3 formed in the battery system can be easily collected as a net product without circulating the electrolyte. Moreover, the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX has a long durability, evidenced by 70 h of operation at −0.4 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, which is the highest among the MXene-based electrocatalysts reported thus far. This work may provide a new methodology based on Zn-N2 battery for sustainable and large-scale NH3 production with minimal energy consumption. Keywords NH3 production Zn-N2 battery N2 Electroreduction Nb2O5/Nb2CTX heterostructure 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) plays an important role in both fertilizer and modern chemical industry, and has been recognized as a promising energy carrier and carbon-free fuel due to its high energy density and low liquefaction point [1–3]. Each year, ∼1.3% of the global CO2 emission is generated by the energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process that consumes ∼2% of the energy for NH3 production across the world, exacerbating the energy shortages and climate change [4–6]. Therefore, it is urgently desired to develop new NH3 synthesis strategies to meet the high demand for NH3 at the same time to reduce the energy consumption and environment impact [7]. Electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (ENRR) provides a green and sustainable alternative to the traditional Haber-Bosch process, as it can realize N2 conversion to NH3 under ambient conditions and can be powered by renewable electricity [8,9]. Nevertheless, the NH3 yield and Faradaic efficiency (FE) of ENRR are still far below the expectations for industrial applications due to several key issues including the stable N≡N triple bond, the low solubility of N2 in aqueous electrolytes, the competitive hydrogen reduction reaction (HER), and the high anode overpotential of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [10–12]. In addition, the catalyst deactivation and the degradation of the separation membrane by reactive oxygen species also shorten the operation time of the ENRR system, leading to high cost of the NH3 production [13]. How to tackle the above issues while achieving high ENRR performance and low energy consumption remains a key challenge for the catalysis community thus far. Zn-N2 batteries endowed with environmentally friendly nature have been demonstrated to be capable of delivering high power density [14]. Typically, a rechargeable aqueous Zn-N2 battery is made of an ENRR catalyst as the cathode, a piece of Zn foil as the anode, and the N2-saturated aqueous solution as the electrolyte, respectively. During the discharging process, N2 is converted to NH3 in the cathode over the electrocatalyst; simultaneously, Zn is oxidized to ZnO or Zn(OH)4 2− in the anode in KOH solution electrolyte. During the charging process, ZnO or Zn(OH)4 2− is reduced to metallic Zn and O2 is formed in situ through oxygen evolution reaction, resulting in the energy conversion and storage [15]. The energy generation and the NH3 synthesis can be integrated together in a rechargeable aqueous Zn-N2 battery system that can produce NH3 with little energy input. To date, several studies on Zn-N2 batteries have been demonstrated the feasibility and potential of this strategy for the co-production of NH3 and electricity [16]. Chen et al. employed OV-Ti2O3/CP as the cathode of the Zn-N2 battery to achieve a power density of 1.02 mW cm−2 with an NH3 yield of 4.3 μg h−1 mgcat −1 in an acidic electrolyte [15]. Lv et al. intelligently designed and fabricated an iron-doped titanium dioxide hollow nanosphere with abundant oxygen vacancies (Fe1.0HTNS) that was used to assemble a Zn-N2 battery, realizing an NH3 yield of 0.172 μg h−1 cm−2 and a power density of 16.42 μW cm−2 [17]. However, the performances of these batteries are below the expectations in terms of low power density and NH3 yield [10]. The cathode electrocatalyst is the key, governing the recharging capacity and stability of the Zn-N2 batteries. As such, the design and fabrication of efficient, stable ENRR catalysts are highly required to achieve efficient NH3 synthesis in Zn-N2 batteries. According to previous theoretical and experimental studies, niobium (Nb) holds great potential in fabricating efficient ENRR electrocatalyst because its d orbital can facilitate the “acceptance-donation” interaction between Nb and N2 molecule, where it accepts lone pair electrons from N2 and injects its electrons to activate the antibonding orbital of N2, leading to an enhanced N2 adsorption and activation capacity [18–21]. In addition, its abundant oxidation states enable a tuned electrochemical activity toward ENRR. For example, Sun and coworkers decorated Nb2O5 nanowire on carbon cloth as a free-standing electrocatalyst and achieved an NH3 yield rate of 1.58 × 10−10 mol s cm−2 at −0.6 V in 0.1 M Na2SO4 with a FE of 2.26%, emphasizing the important role of Nb active sites in ENRR [20]. The combination of Nb catalyst with ideal support can maximize the exposed active sites, enhance the charge transfer between the active sites and the collector, and promote the mass transfer, which may help to develop a more efficient Nb-based ENRR catalyst. MXenes, a novel family of two-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides/carbonitrides/nitrides, have emerged as promising catalysts and supports for ENRR owing to their tunable surface and electronic properties, abundant chemical compositions, large surface area, and high electroconductivity [22,23]. The in situ growth of oxides on corresponding MXenes with the same metal element can not only integrate merits of each component into derived composites, but also enable a strong connection between the oxides and the conductive substrate MXenes for enhancing interfacial charge transfer efficiency during the ENRR process [24–26]. In addition, the formation of metal oxide/MXene heterostructures can redistribute the electron density of each component and thus tune the catalytic activity [27]. Herein, the noble-metal-free heterostructure electrocatalyst, Nb2O5/Nb2CTX, was synthesized through in-situ growing Nb2O5 on the surface of Nb2CTX MXene via hydrothermal reaction by using Nb2CTX as the Nb source. The obtained Nb2O5/Nb2CTX is an efficient, stable ENRR electrocatalyst, evidenced by its optimal NH3 yield rate of 21.43 ± 0.6 μg h−1 mgcat −1 at −0.5 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode (vs. RHE) and an optimized FE of 14.65% ± 1.17% at −0.4 V vs. RHE in alkaline media, outperforming pristine Nb2O5 and most other MXene-based ENRR catalysts previously reported [28–30]. Notably, the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX electrocatalyst demonstrates remarkably high stability and durability for up to 70 h, surpassing the most reported ENRR catalysts in terms of stability. In addition, the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX-based Zn-N2 battery demonstrates a power density of up to 1.25 mW cm−2 with an average NH3 yield rate of 3.62 µg h−1 mg cat −1 in 1.0 M KOH. In particular, the obtained NH3 can be readily separated from the battery system and captured by an acidic trap without circulating the electrolyte, which significantly reduces the requirements on the equipment and cuts down the production cost of NH3. This study provides a simple and efficient way for fabricating high-performance MXene-based electrocatalyst for ENRR and beyond, and sheds light on the development of Zn-N2 batteries as promising techniques for energy conversion and storage. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Nb2CTX MXene Nb2CTX MXene was prepared by the conventional HF etching method [31]. Specifically, 1 g of Nb2AlC MAX powder was slowly added to 20 mL 40% HF solution and stirred at room temperature for 120 h. The resulting mixture was centrifugated, washed with ultra-pure water for several times, and dried at 60 °C in a vacuum oven for 12 h to obtain the Nb2CTX MXene. 2.2 Preparation of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX heterostructure Firstly, 0.5 g Nb2CTX was dispersed in 40 mL ultra-pure water and stirred for 30 min to form a homogeneous mixture. Then, the resulting mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel reactor and heated at 180 °C for 12 h. Finally, the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX heterostructure was obtained after centrifugation, washing with ultra-pure water, and vacuum drying at 60 °C overnight. 2.3 Preparation of Nb2O5 Firstly, 2 g of niobium oxalate was placed into a porcelain boat and calcined at 650 °C in a muffle furnace for 3 h. Then, the Nb2O5 was obtained after washing with ultra-pure water and drying at 60 °C for 12 h in a vacuum drying oven. 2.4 ENRR measurements An H-type two-compartment electrolysis cell was used for the ENRR measurements, in which the cathode and anode compartments were separated by a Nafion 117 membrane. All electrochemical experiments were carried out via a classic three-electrode configuration, using Ag/AgCl electrode (3.5 M KCl) as the reference electrode (RE), carbon rod as the counter electrode (CE), and the carbon cloth supported catalyst as the working electrode (WE). The electrolyte in each chamber was 70 mL of 0.1 M KHCO3 solution. Prior to each electrochemical test, ultra-pure nitrogen (99.999%) or ultra-pure argon (99.999%) was bubbled for 30 min with a constant flow rate of 20 mL min−1. All reference electrodes were calibrated concerning the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) and their potentials were in accordance with the Nernst equation (E (RHE) = E (Ag/AgCl) + 0.059 × pH + 0.205). The electrochemical performances of the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX based Zn-N2 battery were measured using a homemade battery configuration as shown in Fig. S1. The carbon paper supported Nb2O5/Nb2CTX (denoted as Nb2O5/Nb2CTX/CP) and Zn plate were used as the cathode and the anode, respectively, with 1.0 M KOH used as the electrolyte. Throughout the entire electrochemical measurements, ultra-pure N2 was continuously supplied to the cathode at a constant flow rate of 50 mL min−1. The outlet gas was passed into 0.01 M H2SO4 solution to absorb the NH3 that is produced and spilled from the battery system. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterizations Fig. 1 depicts the synthesis process of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX heterostructure. Initially, Nb2AlC MAX was etched by HF solution at room temperature for removing the Al layers to obtain the accordion-like Nb2CTX MXene. During the etching process, –OH, –O, and –F functional groups were introduced to the surface of the Nb2CTX MXene layers. Subsequently, Nb2O5 nanoparticles with different sizes and morphologies were generated in situ on the surface and between the Nb2CTX MXene layers through hydrothermal reaction, which will help expose more Nb active sites and facilitate the contact between the N2 reactants and the Nb sites. Importantly, the construction of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX heterostructure can effectively tune the electron density of Nb atoms for regulating their adsorption capacities of N2 and other reduction intermediates, which are important for their ENRR performances. The reference sample of Nb2O5 was synthesized by calcination of niobium oxalate at high temperature. The crystal structure of the as-synthesized samples was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD). As shown in Fig. 2 (a), after etching with 40% HF solution for 120 h (pink curve), the obtained sample exhibits diffraction peaks at 33.4° and 58.8°, which can be attributed to the characteristic diffraction peaks of Nb2CTX MXene (JCPDS, No. 19-0870) [32], indicating the formation of Nb2CTX MXene. The diffraction peak at ∼8.9° is assigned to the (002) crystal plane of Nb2CTX MXene, which exhibits an obvious shift to small angle compared to that of Nb2AlC MAX (∼12.8°) due to the increase of the d layer spacing after removing the Al layers [33]. Additionally, the diffraction peaks at 34.7° and 40.3° align with the characteristic diffraction peaks of NbC (JCPDS, No. 38-1364) [34], attributed to the presence of NbC in the Nb2AlC MAX precursor (light-blue curve). After the hydrothermal reaction (blue curve), new diffraction peaks were observed at 22.6°, 28.4°, 36.6°, 46.2°, 50.8°, and 55.1°, corresponding to the (001), (180), (181), (002), (380), and (182) planes of Nb2O5 (JCPDS, No. 30-0873), indicating the successful preparation of the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX heterostructure. The XRD pattern of as-synthesized Nb2O5 depicted in Fig. S2 is in good agreement with the orthorhombic crystal system (JCPDS, No. 30-0873) [21]. The morphology and structure of the as-prepared samples were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The morphology and structure of as-synthesized Nb2O5 are depicted in Fig. S3. As shown in the SEM image and corresponding elemental mappings (Fig. S4), the Nb2AlC MAX exhibits a blocky structure with Nb, C, and Al elements uniformly distributed on its surface. After etching with HF solution, the Al layers in the Nb2AlC MAX were removed and the accordion-like Nb2CTX MXene was obtained as shown in Fig. 2(b). The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of Nb2CTX (Fig. 2c) displays lattice spacing of ∼0.368 and ∼0.425 nm corresponding to the (021) and (111) planes of Nb2C. After the hydrothermal treatment, Nb2O5 nanoparticles were uniformly formed on the surface of Nb2CTX MXene with some columnar Nb2O5 formed between the layers as depicted in the SEM images of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX with different magnification (Fig. 2d and e). The TEM image of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX (Fig. 2f) further reveals the uniform dispersion of Nb2O5 nanoparticles and columns on the surface and between the layers of Nb2CTX MXene, where the Nb2CTX not only acts as Nb resources for the in-situ growth of Nb2O5, but also acts as a substrate for preventing Nb2O5 from agglomeration. At the same time, the as-formed Nb2O5 effectively prevents Nb2CTX MXene from stacking, which is be conducive to the exposure of Nb active sites and infiltration of electrolyte. Fig. 2(g) displays the HRTEM image and its corresponding selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX. The observed lattice spacing of ∼0.853 nm corresponds to the (002) plane of Nb2CTX. The measured lattice spacings of 0.317 and 0.244 nm are corresponding to the (180) and (181) planes of Nb2O5 supported on Nb2CTX as shown in Fig. 2(g and h). Furthermore, the energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS) analysis revealed a homogeneous distribution of Nb, C, and O throughout the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX (Fig. 2i), indicating the successful synthesis of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX. The defects and disorder degree of the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX, Nb2AlC, and Nb2CTX samples were investigated by Raman spectra. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the intensity ratio of D-band (∼1350 cm−1) to G-band (∼1580 cm−1) (I D/I G) is 0.756, 0.782, and 1.001 for Nb2AlC, Nb2CTX, and Nb2O5/Nb2CTX, respectively, indicating the increased defects with the etching treatment and the introduction of Nb2O5 on the surface of Nb2CTX [34]. These defects will be beneficial for regulating the electronic structure of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX, which in turn affect their electrochemical catalytic performance [35]. The presence of the Nb–O–Nb bond and the [O–Nb–O] n bond is confirmed by the stretching vibrations observed at 674 and 880 cm−1 in the Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra (Fig. 3b) [36]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to analyze the surface compositions and valence states of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX, Nb2AlC, and Nb2CTX. As shown in Fig. 3(c), the disappearance of the characteristic peak at ∼75.0 eV corresponding to Al 2p in the survey scan spectra of Nb2CTX and Nb2O5/Nb2CTX confirms the successful removing of Al layers after HF etching. The XPS survey spectrum of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX exhibits the characteristic peaks of Nb, C, and O, which is consistent with the EDS analysis. As shown in Fig. 3(d) (upper), the high-resolution Nb 3d spectrum of Nb2CTX exhibits two peaks at 209.3 and 206.5 eV assigned to the Nb 3d 3/2 and Nb 3d 5/2 of Nb–O bond, revealing the presence of oxides or O-functional groups on the surface of Nb2CTX [37]. The characteristic peaks of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX at 209.5 and 206.7 eV are attributed to the Nb 3d 3/2 and Nb 3d 5/2 of Nb–O bond, respectively (Fig. 3d, lower). In comparison with Nb2CTX, these two peaks exhibit ∼0.2 eV shift towards high binding energy, indicating a decrease in the electron density of the 3d orbitals of Nb atoms, which is conducive to accepting more electron from N2 for promoting the adsorption of N2 [38]. In addition, the peak at 207.5 eV is attributed to Nb–F terminal group, which is introduced during the etching process. As shown in Fig. 3(e, upper), the characteristic peaks located at 281.8, 284.6, 285.7, 288.7, and 292.5 eV in the high-resolution C 1s spectra of Nb2CTX are attributed to Nb–C, C–C, C–O, C=O, and C–F bonds, respectively [32,39]. The high-resolution F 1s XPS spectrum of Nb2CTX (Fig. S5a) shows characteristic peaks at 689.1 and 683.7 eV attributed to C–F and Nb–F bonds. In comparison, the high-resolution F 1s spectrum of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX exhibits only one characteristic peak at 683.7 eV attributed to the Nb–F bond as shown in the Fig. S5(b). The decreased intensity of this characteristic peak (Nb–F) suggests that the substitution of other terminals for F occurred during the oxidation treatment, which will help improve the ENRR activity of the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX [40]. The high-resolution O 1s XPS spectrum of Nb2CTX (Fig. 3f, upper) exhibits four peaks at 529.6, 530.7, 531.6, and 532.8 eV, which can be ascribed to Nb–O, Nb–C–O x , C–Nb–(OH) x , and C=O, respectively [37]. Furthermore, a negative shift of 0.2 eV in the binding energy of the O 1s XPS spectrum of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX relative to Nb2CTX underscores the lower valence state of the O atoms in Nb2O5/Nb2CTX electrocatalyst compared to the Nb2CTX MXene. 3.2 Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction The ENRR performances of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX were evaluated using a standard three-electrode system in a H-cell. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements were firstly conducted in Ar- and N2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 solution under ambient conditions. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the LSV curve in the N2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 demonstrates a higher current density compared to that in the Ar-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte when the applied potential is below −0.2 V vs. RHE, indicating the electrocatalytic activity of the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX for ENRR. Fig. 4(b) shows the chronoamperometric (CA) curves obtained at the applied potentials ranging from −0.3 to −0.7 V vs. RHE for each 2 h. The stable current densities at the applied potentials indicate the excellent stability of the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX electrocatalyst. The standard curve and the ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) absorption spectra of the electrolytes stained with indophenol blue indicator after electrocatalysis for 2 h at different potentials are presented in Figs. S6 and S7. As shown in Fig. 4(c), the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX electrode demonstrates its maximal NH3 yield rate of 21.43 μg h−1 mgcat −1 at −0.5 V vs. RHE and its highest FE of 14.65% at −0.4 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M KHCO3. These ENRR performances of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX outperform most state-of-the-art noble-metal-free MXene-based ENRR electrocatalysts under ambient conditions as shown in Table S1. Especially, the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX exhibits more favorable NH3 yield and FE at low potential in alkaline electrolyte compared with other MXene-based electrocatalysts. For instance, the FE of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX is approximately 1.74 times higher than that of TiO2/Ti3C2TX (8.4%) [41] and 2.01 times higher than that of Ni@Nb2C (7.3%) [42]. The NH3 yield of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX surpasses almost all MXenes, being 1.45 times greater than that of three-dimensional (3D) Ti3C2TX (14.8 µg h−1 mgcat −1) [43], 1.05 times of V4C3TX (20.41 µg h−1 mgcat −1) and 2.05 times of Mo2CTX (10.43 µg h−1 mgcat −1) [44]. The NH3 yield and FE are significantly reduced as the potential becomes more negative due to the increasing HER, which occupies the active sites and hinders the effective adsorption of N2 molecules [45]. The produced NH3 was further quantified using ammonia gas-sensitive electrode method to ensure the reliability of the indophenol blue method. The standard curve correlating with concentration and potential is shown in Fig. S8. As depicted in Fig. S9, the NH3 yields determined by the ammonia gas-sensitive electrode align with those obtained by indophenol blue spectrophotometry, affirming the accuracy and dependability of the results obtained by indophenol blue method. A series of comparative experiments were carried out to determine the source of the detected NH3. First, electrolysis experiment was conducted at −0.4 V vs. RHE in Ar-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 for 2 h. As shown in Fig. 4(d) (pink curve), the obtained UV-vis spectrum represents no NH3 detected in the absence of N2, indicating that the influence of the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX catalyst and environment on the detection of produced NH3 was negligible. Then, the undetected NH3 in the N2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte after electrolyzing at open-circuit potential (OCP) for 2 h demonstrates that the ENRR needs to be carried out at the applied potentials (Fig. 4d, orange curve). As shown in Fig. 4(e), the NH3 yields and corresponding FEs obtained at −0.4 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M KHCO3 by alternately using N2 and Ar as feed gas further confirm that the produced NH3 originates from ENRR rather than external contamination. Hydrazine (N2H4) is a potential solution-phase by-product of ENRR, which can be determined by the Watt-Chrisp method [38]. The standard N2H4 curve is provided in Fig. S10. According to our experiments (Fig. 4f), there is no N2H4 in the N2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte after electrolyzing for 2 h at −0.4 V vs. RHE, indicating the good selectivity of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX for NH3 production. The ENRR performances of Nb2AlC, Nb2CTX, Nb2O5, and Nb2O5/Nb2CTX were evaluated under the same experimental conditions to investigate the role of each component and the relationship between the structure of the catalysts and theirs ENRR activities. As shown in Fig. 4(g), the Nb2AlC MAX obtains the highest NH3 yield of 6.57 μg h−1 mgcat −1 at the high potential of −0.7 V vs. RHE, which is only 30.66% that of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX (21.43 μg h−1 mgcat −1 at −0.5 V vs. RHE). After treating with HF solution, the obtained Nb2CTX MXene achieves a better NH3 yield of 13.99 μg h−1 mgcat −1 at the potential of −0.4 V vs. RHE than its precursor mainly due to the facile exposure of Nb active sites and the good conductivity of the 2D structure formed by removing the Al layers [28]. Impressively, the NH3 yield of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX obtained at −0.5 V vs. RHE (21.43 μg h−1 mgcat −1) is almost 2.73 times higher than that of Nb2CTX MXene (7.86 μg h−1 mgcat −1), highlighting the significant role of the in-situ growth of Nb2O5 on Nb2CTX MXene for improving the ENRR performances. This NH3 yield is also 1.33 times as high as that of Nb2O5 (16.12 μg h−1 mgcat −1) at the same applied potential with the help of the Nb2CTX MXene, which provides a large surface area for supporting Nb2O5 and accelerates the electron transfer from the current collector to Nb2O5. Fig. 4(h) shows that the FE of the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX (14.65% at −0.4 V vs. RHE) is much higher than that of Nb2AlC (2.48%), Nb2CTX (4.19%), and Nb2O5 (4.86%), indicating that the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX exhibits superior selectivity for ENRR. Additionally, the electrocatalytic activity of the as-prepared Nb2O5/Nb2CTX in neutral media was also evaluated in 0.1 M Na2SO4. The calibration curve of the standard NH3 solution and the corresponding UV-vis absorbance spectra obtained by the indophenol blue method are shown in Fig. S11. The UV-vis absorbance spectra of the electrolytes after 2 h of ENRR tests at five selected potentials demonstrate the successful synthesis of NH3 by Nb2O5/Nb2CTX catalyst in 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte (Fig. S12). As shown in Fig. 4(i), Nb2O5/Nb2CTX exhibits its optimal NH3 yield of 11.17 μg h−1 mgcat −1 with corresponding FE of 6.19% at −0.4 V vs. RHE in neutral electrolyte. The electrocatalytic performance of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX catalyst in alkaline electrolyte is significantly higher than that in neutral media partly because of the limited proton concentration in an alkaline medium that effectively inhibits the competitive HER reaction and thus enhances the selectivity of ENRR to some extent. The as-fabricated Nb2O5/Nb2CTX exhibits outstanding catalytic performances for ENRR mainly due to the following reasons. Firstly, Nb2CTX MXene with good electroconductivity realizes the fast electron transfer from the collector to the Nb active sites and thus accelerates the reaction rate as demonstrated by the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), the charge transfer resistance (R ct) of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX is lower than that of Nb2O5, Nb2CTX, and Nb2AlC, which is favor for charge and electron transport [46]. At the same time, the typical 2D structure of Nb2CTX MXene provides large surface area for confining Nb2O5 and exposing sufficient active sites for ENRR. The double-layer capacitance (C dl) was estimated by cyclic voltammetry measurements at various sweep speeds (Fig. S13). As shown in Fig. 5(b), the C dl of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX (3.73 mF cm−2) is much higher than that of Nb2O5 (1.50 mF cm−2), Nb2CTX (2.78 mF cm−2), and Nb2AlC (1.69 mF cm−2), indicating that Nb2O5/Nb2CTX provides more active sites for ENRR [47]. Moreover, the strong hydrophobicity of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX, as characterized by contact angle measurement (Fig. 5c), effectively inhibits the HER, thereby improving the selectivity of ENRR. Importantly, the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX heterostructure endows the 3d orbitals of Nb atoms with lower electron density than Nb2CTX as evidenced by the XPS analysis, which helps strengthen the Nb–N bond for better adsorption of N2. The insertion of Nb2O5 nanocolumns between the Nb2CTX MXene layers prevents the MXene layers from stacking, which are beneficial to the exposure of Nb active sites and the infiltration of electrolyte for better contact between Nb and N2. Overall, the above factors synergistically ensure good ENRR performances of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX. Except for the selectivity and activity, stability is also a crucial factor for evaluating the ENRR performance of catalysts. The stability of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX was evaluated through 8 cycling tests at −0.4 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M KHCO3. As shown in Fig. 5(d), no significant changes were observed for either the NH3 production rate or FEs over eight consecutive cycles, indicating an outstanding electrochemical stability of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX. In addition, the NRR performance test results after long-time electrolysis show that the total NH3 content increases gradually with the extension of electrolysis time (Fig. S14). The current density of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX exhibits negligible change over a 70-hour continuous electrolysis at −0.4 V vs. RHE (Fig. 5e). The Nb2O5/Nb2CTX heterostructure remains highly active after long-period electrocatalysis up to 70 h, evidenced by only 4.0% decay of the NH3 yield with 12.4% attenuation of the FE (Fig. 5e, inset). To the best of our knowledge, this stability is the best in the reported MXene-based ENRR catalysts. Moreover, the morphology, structure, and chemical composition of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX remain unchanged after long-term electrolysis (Fig. 5f–h and Fig. S15). These results further demonstrate the excellent stability of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX during ENRR testing conducted in N2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 and highlight the strategy of in-situ decorating metallic oxides on corresponding MXenes in the design and fabrication of stable, efficient ENRR catalysts and other electrocatalysis. 3.3 Rechargeable aqueous Zn-N2 battery In view of the excellent ENRR performances, the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX heterostructure demonstrates great potential as catalyst for aqueous rechargeable Zn-N2 batteries, which can realize artificial NH3 synthesis and energy generation under ambient condition at the same time. For the discharge process of this aqueous Zn-N2 battery, the cathode reaction is N2 + 6 H2O + 6 e− → 2 NH3 + 6 OH−, the anode follows the reaction of Zn + 2 OH− → ZnO + H2O + 2 e−, and the overall reaction is 3 Zn + N2 + 3 H2O → 3 ZnO + 2 NH3. During the charge process, the anode reaction is 4 OH−→ O2 + 2 H2O + 4 e−, the cathode reaction is ZnO + H2O + 2 e− → Zn + 2 OH−, and the overall reaction is 2 ZnO → 2 Zn + O2. To this end, we employed the carbon paper-supported Nb2O5/Nb2CTX as cathode and Zn foil as anode to construct the Zn-N2 battery with N2-sturated 1.0 M KOH solution as the electrolyte (Fig. 6 a). According to the galvanostatic discharge polarization curve shown in Fig. 6(b) and Fig. S16, the peak power density of Zn-N2 battery is calculated to be 1.253 mW cm−2 at the discharge current density of 4.5 mA cm−2, which is significantly higher than that of reported Zn-N2 batteries as summarized in Table S2, for example Fe-2HSC-8 (155.52 μW cm−2) and CoPi/HSNPC (0.31 mW cm−2) [14,48]. The OCP of the as-constructed battery (Fig. 6c) reaches 1.17 V vs. Zn/Zn2+, consistent with the discharge test results. The Nb2O5/Nb2CTX-based Zn-N2 battery was then discharged at different current densities ranging from 5 to 20 μA cm−2 for each 1 h to evaluate its NH3 production performance. As plotted in Fig. 6(d), the obtained battery exhibits the highest NH3 yield of 3.86 μg h−1 mgcat −1 during discharge process at the current density of 5 μA cm−2. Especially, the NH3 yield returns to 3.64 μg h−1 mgcat −1 when the current density turns to 5 μA cm−2, demonstrating the excellent stability of the present Zn-N2 battery system. To investigate the long-term charging and discharging capacity of the Zn-N2 battery, galvanostatic charge for 4 h and discharge for 6 h were conducted at the current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 and 5 μA cm−2, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6(e), the battery delivers a relatively stable charging capability within 4 h, during which the OER take place to realize the energy conversion and storage. The galvanostatic discharge curve of the Zn-N2 battery is depicted in Fig. 6(f). The average NH3 yield rate during each hour was obtained by determining the concentration of the spilled NH3 in the acidic trap. The Zn-N2 battery can continuously generate NH3 during the 6 h of discharge process. Then, the discharge-charge processes were carried out for six cycles. The accumulated NH3 yields after each cycle are presented in Fig. 6(g). The steady increase in NH3 yield over six cycles indicates the stable catalytic performance of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX in the present Zn-N2 battery system. Notably, the Zn-N2 battery can realize continuous NH3 production with a stable yield during 6 charge-discharge cycles, which is more efficient than the long-term continuous discharge process for the same period. This may be due to that the charge-discharge cycle can avoid the severe corrosion, passivation, and dendrite growth of the Zn anode during extended period of discharge, which significantly increases its NH3 production performances. For investigating the cycling capacity and the continuous NH3 production capacity, long-term cycling tests were conducted. The galvanostatic charge-discharge cycling curves of Nb2O5/Nb2CTX-based Zn-N2 battery are illustrated in Fig. 6(h). The assembled battery exhibits a comparable stability with nearly stable discharging and charging voltage platforms for 5 cycles with reasonable NH3 yield rate during each discharge process (Fig. 6i), demonstrating the good cycling stability for the continuous NH3 production of the present battery system. 4 Conclusions In summary, Nb2O5/Nb2CTX heterojunction was simply fabricated via in situ oxidation of Nb2CTX MXene through hydrothermal treatment and demonstrated as efficient, stable electrocatalyst for both ENRR and the high-active cathode for Zn-N2 battery. Benefitting from the enhanced N2 adsorption and activation capacity endowed by the reduced electron density of Nb 3d orbitals, the adequate exposed Nb active sites, the good electron and mass transfer, as well as the hydrophobicity, this Nb2O5/Nb2CTX catalyst exhibits an outstanding ENRR activity and selectivity in alkaline media, evidenced by an optimal NH3 yield of 21.43 ± 0.6 µg−1 mgcat −1 at −0.5 V vs. RHE and an optimal FE of 14.65% ± 1.17% at −0.4 V vs. RHE with a high stability of up to 70 h. More importantly, the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX based rechargeable Zn-N2 battery realizes a high peak density of 1.25 mW cm−2, which stands out among those reported Zn-N2 batteries. At the same time, it achieves an average NH3 yield rate of 3.62 µg h−1 mgcat −1 in 1.0 M KOH, of which the produced NH3 can be easily collected without cycling the electrolyte. This work establishes a facile yet effective approach for the rational design and fabrication of MXene-based ENRR electrocatalysts, and provides a promising device with high power density for simultaneous NH3 production and electricity generation. coredata.dc:description: Aqueous Zn-N2 batteries with unique configuration are of potential for simultaneous N2 electroreduction and electricity generation, in which the electrocatalysts are critical for improving the NH3 yield and the energy efficiency. Herein, a heterostructure Nb2O5/Nb2CTX with abundant exposed Nb active sites and tuned electron density has been synthesized by in situ formation and anchoring of Nb2O5 nanoparticles on the surface of Nb2CTX MXene, which shows an enhanced N2 adsorption/activation capacity. The heterostructure Nb2O5/Nb2CTX was used as the cathode of Zn-N2 battery that can deliver a peak power density of 1.25 mW cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH and can continuously produce NH3 with a yield of 3.62 μg h−1 mgcat −1. The NH3 formed in the battery system can be easily collected as a net product without circulating the electrolyte. Moreover, the Nb2O5/Nb2CTX has a long durability, evidenced by 70 h of operation at −0.4 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, which is the highest among the MXene-based electrocatalysts reported thus far. This work may provide a new methodology based on Zn-N2 battery for sustainable and large-scale NH3 production with minimal energy consumption.
